Product Notation in Monoids

For a monoid $M$ and elements $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{n} \in M$, the product is defined as $\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i} := a_{1} \cdot \ldots \cdot a_{n}$. A special bracketing on the right-hand side is not necessary due to the associative nature of the law of composition.
Factor Group

Given a normal subgroup $N \subset G$ of a group $G$, the factor group or the residue class group of $G$ modulo $N$, denoted $G / N$, is the group formed by the set of left cosets of $N$ in $G$ with the group operation defined by $(aN) \cdot (bN) = (ab)N$ for $a, b \in G$.
Integral Domain
A commutative ring R is called an integral domain if it is nonzero and does not admit nontrivial zero divisors.
Ring Homomorphism

Let $R$ and $R'$ be rings. A map $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called a ring homomorphism if it satisfies two conditions: (i) $\varphi(a+b)=\varphi(a)+\varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$, making $\varphi$ a group homomorphism with respect to addition, and (ii) $\varphi(a \cdot b)=\varphi(a) \cdot \varphi(b)$ for all $a, b \in R$ and $\varphi(1)=1$, making $\varphi$ a monoid homomorphism with respect to multiplication.
Image of a Ring Homomorphism
Let $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ be a ring homomorphism. The image of $\varphi$, denoted $\operatorname{im} \varphi$, is defined as $\varphi(R)$, which is a subring of $R'$.
Primitive Polynomial

A polynomial $f \in R[X]$ with coefficients in a unique factorization domain $R$ is called primitive if the greatest common divisor of all its coefficients is 1, or equivalently, if $
u_p(f) = 0$ for all prime elements $p \in R$.
Characteristic of a field

Let $K$ be a field (or, more generally, an integral domain) and let $\varphi: \mathbb{Z} \longrightarrow K$ be the canonical ring homomorphism. Furthermore, let $p \in \mathbb{N}$ be a generating element of the principal ideal $\operatorname{ker} \varphi$. Then $p$ is called the characteristic of $K$, and we write $p=\operatorname{char} K$.
Algebraically closed field

A field $K$ is called algebraically closed if every nonconstant polynomial $f$ of $K[X]$ admits a zero in $K$, or in other words, if $f$ decomposes in $K[X]$ into a product of linear factors. This means that $f$ admits a product decomposition $f=c \prod_{i}\left(X-\alpha_{i}\right)$ with a constant $c \in K^{*}$ as well as zeros $\alpha_{i} \in K$.
Splitting Field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield

A field $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ is a splitting field of a polynomial $X^q-X$ over its prime subfield $\\[\mathbb{F}_p\]$ if the polynomial factorizes into linear factors in $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$. This implies that $\\[\mathbb{F}\]$ contains all zeros of $X^q-X$.
Galois group of a Field Extension
The Galois group $\\operatorname{Gal}(L / K)$ of an extension $L / K$ is the group of all field automorphisms of $L$ that fix every element of $K$.
Normalizer
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The normalizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $N_{S}=\{x \in G ; x S=S x\}$.
Set
A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.
Inheritance_Analysis

Generalization_Specialization_Relationsh.Explanation: A field is a special type of integral domain, and the characteristic of a field (ID: 6) is a concept that applies to integral domains (ID: 2) in general.
